meanings.definition: To speak or perform without preparation
meanings.sent1: During the talent show, Sarah had to extemporize a dance routine when the music suddenly stopped.
meanings.sent2: The comedian had to extemporize a joke when the audience requested a new one.
meanings.sent3: In the play, the actor had to extemporize a line when he forgot his script, leading to unexpected laughter from the audience.
meanings.sent4: The chef had to extemporize a new dish when a key ingredient ran out, resulting in a surprisingly delicious creation.
meanings.sent5: The teacher had to extemporize a science experiment when the original one failed, sparking curiosity in the students.

meanings.definition: To improvise or make up on the spot
meanings.sent1: The storyteller would often extemporize tales to entertain the children around the campfire.
meanings.sent2: The musician had to extemporize a guitar solo during the live performance when his sheet music flew away.
meanings.sent3: The detective had to extemporize a cover story to gain access to the suspect's house.
meanings.sent4: The artist would extemporize new designs when inspiration struck, creating unique and vibrant artwork.
meanings.sent5: The explorer had to extemporize a shelter using only the materials found in the wilderness, showcasing his survival skills.
